dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, B, we've been seeing a lot of talk lately about, um, 'Buy American' policies, right? It seems like the US is getting pretty protectionist.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, B, we've been seeing a lot of talk lately about, um, Buy American policies, right? It seems like the U S is getting pretty protectionist.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In fact, contrary to most analysts expectations, the United States has imposed additional protectionist measures, such as Bidens buy American policies, resulting in higher costs for American consumers and taxpayers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, A, totally. And it's not just Biden, like, Trump really kicked things off with those tariffs on steel and aluminum, remember?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, A, totally. And it's not just Biden, like, Trump really kicked things off with those tariffs on steel and aluminum, remember?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: During Donald Trumps presidency, the US imposed a 25% tariff on steel imports and a 10% tariff on imported aluminum.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. And the China trade war, and the TPP exit... but Biden's actually gone, like, even further with things like the IRA and the CHIPS Act.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. And the China trade war, and the T P P exit... but Biden's actually gone, like, even further with things like the I R A and the C H I P S Act.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Biden administration, however, has gone even further, fully embracing industrial policy by enacting the $430 billion Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), which includes hundreds of billions of dollars in subsidies for green technologies and renewable energies, and the $280 billion CHIPS and Science Act, aimed at fostering a robust US semiconductor industry.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. The Inflation Reduction Act, uh, pouring billions into green tech, and the CHIPS Act, you know, trying to boost our semiconductor industry here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. The Inflation Reduction Act, uh, pouring billions into green tech, and the C H I P S Act, you know, trying to boost our semiconductor industry here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Biden administration, however, has gone even further, fully embracing industrial policy by enacting the $430 billion Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), which includes hundreds of billions of dollars in subsidies for green technologies and renewable energies, and the $280 billion CHIPS and Science Act, aimed at fostering a robust US semiconductor industry.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which, on the surface, sounds good, but it's, um, effectively discriminating against foreign producers with those subsidies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, on the surface, sounds good, but it's, um, effectively discriminating against foreign producers with those subsidies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By subsidizing US-based companies, however, the bill effectively discriminates against foreign and overseas producers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Like, the EV tax credit for US-made cars, giving them an advantage. But studies show subsidies often backfire.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Like, the E V tax credit for U S-made cars, giving them an advantage. But studies show subsidies often backfire.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Similarly, the IRA provides a $7,500 subsidy to purchasers of US-made electric vehicles (EVs), giving American-made models an advantage over their Chinese and Japanese rivals. But studies have repeatedly shown that subsidies often harm the countries implementing them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they can stifle innovation, raise costs for consumers... [overlaps] And it leads to a huge problem: retaliation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they can stifle innovation, raise costs for consumers... And it leads to a huge problem: retaliation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Such measures tend to reduce competition, stifle innovation, raise costs, and disadvantage exporters who rely on imported inputs. Worse yet, when one country introduces subsidies to enhance the competitiveness of domestic producers, other countries typically counter with protectionist policies of their own. And retaliation and tit-for-tat escalation damages the economies of other countries and their trading partners.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Exactly! We're already seeing it. The EU's got their own chip plan, South Korea, Japan too. Everyone's doing it now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! We're already seeing it. The E U's got their own chip plan, South Korea, Japan too. Everyone's doing it now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In response to Bidens industrial policies, for example, the European Union has recently greenlit a 43 billion ($47 billion) plan to bolster its semiconductor industry, while South Korea and Japan have also rolled out plans to subsidize domestic chip production.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's like a subsidy war, isn't it? And, uh, Morris Chang from TSMC, he even said manufacturing chips here is 50% more expensive than in Taiwan.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like a subsidy war, isn't it? And, uh, Morris Chang from T S M C, he even said manufacturing chips here is fifty percent more expensive than in Taiwan.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Morris Chang, founder of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, has recently estimated that chip manufacturing is 50% more expensive in the US than in Taiwan, where more than 90% of the worlds high-end chips are currently produced.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Fifty percent! So even with these billions, it might not even close that gap. And Adam Posen, he says the real cost isn't trade barriers, it's reduced productivity growth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fifty percent! So even with these billions, it might not even close that gap. And Adam Posen, he says the real cost isn't trade barriers, it's reduced productivity growth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But as Adam Posen of the Peterson Institute for International Economics notes, the true price of economic decoupling is not so much trade barriers, bad as they are, but reduced productivity growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which is, like, a much bigger long-term issue. And all this money, couldn't it be better spent on, um, education or infrastructure?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is, like, a much bigger long-term issue. And all this money, couldn't it be better spent on, um, education or infrastructure?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Redirecting these funds toward education, job training, research, and infrastructure would do far more to enhance industrial competitiveness, both domestically and globally.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Secretary Raimondo's calling the CHIPS Act a blueprint, but if everyone copies it, we're just heading for a massive, budget-busting global subsidy war.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Secretary Raimondo's calling the C H I P S Act a blueprint, but if everyone copies it, we're just heading for a massive, budget-busting global subsidy war.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Regrettably, US Secretary of Commerce Gina Raimondo has recently touted the CHIPS Act as a blueprint for supporting other domestic sectors. Given that other countries will almost certainly respond in kind, it appears that Trumps trade war with China has morphed into a budget-busting global subsidy war that no one can win.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, a war nobody, um, really wins.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, a war nobody, um, really wins.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is already clear that the coming subsidy war will have no clear winners.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Nope. Just higher costs for everyone, really.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nope. Just higher costs for everyone, really.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: the United States has imposed additional protectionist measures, such as Bidens buy American policies, resulting in higher costs for American consumers and taxpayers.
